results.title: A Taste of Hong Kong
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “International cookbook series”.
This video which has detailed demonstrations of traditional Chinese dishes and garnishes is interspersed with views of life in Hong Kong, particularly the markets, the restaurants and the harbour. It is divided into five sections: “Delights of the heart” which covers breakfasts and dim sum, “Treasures from the sea”, “Meat roasts”, “Food and festivals” and “Homecoming”. Demonstrated dishes include spare ribs en papillote, sauteed oysters with spring onion and ginger, roast pork and duck and spiced crispy chicken.

results.title: Co-operative behaviour (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phil Content, Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
Co-operative behaviour enables groups of people to achieve a common goal. Firstly, a common goal must be decided on, and then behaviour co-ordinated between individuals to achieve this goal. Looks at co-operative behaviour in the classroom, and warns against confusing conformity and obedience with co-operation.

results.title: Teacher behavior: an overview (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phil Content, Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”
Looks at the sorts of teacher interaction in the classroom which can either enhance or inhibit children’s learning. It stresses the need for teachers to search out behaviour patterns that encourage learning.

results.title: Aggressive behaviour (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phil Content, Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
Aggression is a concentrated, focussed reaction to lack of security and approval. Within the classroom aggression on the part of teachers can take the form of verbal abuse, stridency and belittling techniques to satisfy the teacher’s need for security at the expense of pupils. The film shows that pupils can respond to this behaviour by aggression in return or by withdrawal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phil Content, Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera and FilmFair Communications

results.title: Closing behaviour (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phil Content, Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera and University of Southern California
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
An introduction to various sorts of closing behaviour often used by the classroom teacher - shifting attention from one child to another, not listening fully to the child’s response - the film points out that too much closing behaviour prevents children developing.

results.title: Supporting behavior (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Phil Content, Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera and Science Research Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”
We all need others to add their strength to our own. In the classroom pupils need support and guidance from teachers to give them the power to cope. A good teacher manages the classroom so that everyone gets a chance to express himself and grow.

results.title: Withdrawal behaviour (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Gesa de Rozner, P. Hefferman-Cabera and Science Research Association
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
Withdrawal is a response to overwhelming threat to identity. This film looks at behaviour in the classroom which can produce a withdrawal in both students and teachers, and indicates how to recognise this behaviour when it is occurring.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gesa de Rozner, P. Hefferman-Cabera and Science Research Association

Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.

results.title: Reciprocating behavior (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera, Phil Content and Science Research Association
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
Because we are all dependent on each other, a voluntary exchange of personal ideas and emotions allows us to develop as individuals. Reciprocating behaviour in the classroom enables the pupils to develop, to become both receiver and giver.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera, Phil Content and Science Research Association
